text:
So first of all I would, like to thank the Chemical
& Engineering News team for giving me this opportunity.

It's a great honor to be one of the alumni
of this Talented 12 class.

This talk is going to be about my personal
journey.

My personal journey starts in Spain in my
hometown.
Currently I'm involved in outreach activities

and when I tell my story to high school students,
normally they think that I became a chemist
because I wanted to be as Marie Curie.

However, I have to tell you that it wasn't
my case.

I became a chemist because I felt different,
because probably I didn't fit in.

As you can imagine, it's not only because
I didn't look as the typical Spanish girl.

It was also because I was really good at science,
in particular, in chemistry.

So, after finishing my high school it was
kind of a rough time.
I decided to pursue my degree in chemistry.

And when I was an undergrad, I started my research
career under the supervision of Professor
Pablo Espinet and Prof. Juan Casares.

With them, I also developed my master's degree
and my PhD.

And during my time at the University of Valladolid,
I focused on understanding experimental approaches

to reaction mechanism of palladium-catalyzed
processes.

Basically, I spent those years trying to unravel
how chemical processes work.

That means normally the in-between stuff between
the starting material and the desired product.
For my family, I was solving puzzles.
It was great. I learned a lot.

However, at the end of my PhD, this was my
situation.

Can you see the light at the end of the tunnel?
Because I couldn't see it.

And indeed, the tunnel is even darker if you think
that after finishing my PhD, there was a lack
of professional opportunities.
That is a big problem that we face in Spain.
However, one day my life changed.

One of my PhD advisors, Juan, attended a symposium,
and you can see here the list of fantastic
plenary speakers.

What he did, he approached one of them, in
particular Prof. Melanie Sanford, and
he talked to her about me.

He called me that night, I was in the lab,
and told me that I had to go immediately to

that symposium because Melanie wanted to meet
me.
So I took a train at 6:00 a.m., and I went there.

I found the courage to approach Melanie because
she was around a lot of people.
I explained to her what I was doing.

I gave her my CV, and after 10 days, I have
a job offer in my email.

So, from here, I want to thank a lot to Juan
for the extra push, and Melanie for giving

me the opportunity to join her lab at the
University of Michigan.

There I kept working with the same metal, with
palladium, but I changed the oxidation state.

What I did there is to study how to tackle
one of the major challenges related to these

high-valent palladium complexes, and it's
how to control the selectivity during the

reductive elimination where more than one
product can be formed.

And in particular, I focused my attention in carbon-nitrogen
bond formation because these types of bonds

are prevalent in agrochemical, material science,
and also drugs.
This was great.
I learned a lot, I mentored students.

I even was a lecturer at the University of
Michigan, however, I needed to decide what
to do in the next stage of my career.
This is a long story in short.
So this was a summary of my decision tree.
I decided that I wanted to stay in academia.

I decided that I wanted to come back to Spain
because my country and different organizations
invested a lot of money in my education.

I wanted to give them back a little bit of
what I had received.

And then it was the hardest question to answer,
whether or not to start my own lab.

Maybe this question is not obvious to us,
and it's not only because as you can hear

the situation for woman in scientific career
in top academic positions is not ideal.
And in Spain, it's even harder.

It was also that the Spanish system works
a little bit different than the American one.
Normally when you finish your...

after a postdoctoral stay abroad, you don't
start your own group.

You join a group of a senior PI, but I didn't
want to do that.

And then I found out there was only a place that
I could apply for a job, so the possibilities
was just reduced to one.

It was the Institute of Chemical Research
of Catalonia.

So after knowing where I should apply for a job,
the one million question was what type of
chemistry I would like to do?

I think that this is summarized in one quote
by Prof. Richard Feynman that is also
now in my current situation.

"Study hard what interests you the most in
the most undisciplined, irreverent, and original
manner possible."

I don't know if you noticed it, but in all
my slides, I have here a hashtag.

This is the hashtag that we use in my group,
and #WeLoveMechanisms.

We love how to understand how chemical processes
work.

If I'm here today, that means that I got the
job.

I was able to come back to Spain, and I joined
ICIQ as one of the junior group leaders.

Since then, I had the privilege to work with
a fantastic group of students.

They not only work really hard, we also know
how to have fun.

We are Spanish, and this is one of the last
pictures from a celebration just a few weeks
ago.
What is our goal?

We want to tackle some of the major problems
that our world faces, such as global warming

and the impact of chemical synthesis, following
a pretty innovative philosophy.

We are focused on the understanding organometallic
processes relevant to catalytic transformation.
Why is this innovative?

Because our goal is not only to provide critical
mechanistic information on well-known reactivity,
but to pursue what we call our U3D goal.

We want to understand, discover, design, and
develop novel and more efficient transition-metal-catalyzed
transformation.

We want to do that by trapping reaction intermediates
and using them as knowledge building blocks
for rational design.

Let's consider any transition-metal-catalyzed
transformation, where we want to go from A
plus B to C.

The traditional approach is to use mechanistic
study as a posteriori tool for understanding
successful transformation.

And for me, this is what represented a successful
transformation, a graceful tango where every
movement is synchronized.
It's elegant.
Everything works perfectly.

However, you will agree with me that most
of the reactions that we put in the lab looks
more like this.
This is less exquisite.
This is less elegant.

Imagine that you know how to design this choreography,
and you have to create a new one.
You will start dancing like this, not right.

You probably would take the knowledge that
you know from all this movement, and you will
design a new one modifying some of them.

The translation of this analogy to chemistry
is the foundation of our research.

From a mechanistic perspective, the success
or failure, at least from our point of view,

of any organic chemical transformation relies
on the performance of the intermediate involved
in the elementary step of a catalytic cycle.

This may seem really obvious but normally it
is overlooked and this can be a completely
game changer for not-efficient transformations.

So we ambition to use mechanistic studies
as a really powerful tool for designing more

efficient transformations by capturing this
reaction intermediate and using them to overcome
limitations and explore innovative reactivity.

So my group, we have two different research
lines.

In one of them, we explore bimetallic system
in order to promote carbon-carbon forming
reactions.

We published the first paper in this line
really recently in Chemistry European Journal

in a special issue that is going to be dedicated
to the 7th EuChemS symposium that is going
to be held next week in Liverpool,

where I'm going to be one of the speakers in
a symposium sponsored by ACS.

If you are around in Liverpool, please go
to see my talk and some of the members of
my lab.

This is the cover that one of my really creative
students designed for this occasion.

If you think that I'm the one in the cover,
it's not true because she doesn't wear glasses,
so of course it's not me.

I'm going to give you just a flavor how we
apply our strategy in our other research line
in our investigation on cobalt complexes.

Probably I don't have to convince you that
one of the ideal methods for the formation

of carbon-carbon and carbon-heteroatom bonds
is through the functionalization of inert
C-H bonds.

Among the different approaches developed over
the past few decades, the transition metal-catalyzed

directed C-H functionalization using nobel
metals such as rhodium and palladium has emerged
as a really powerful tool in organic synthesis.

These strategies offer obvious advantageous
such as the selective C-H bond cleavage due

to the employment of this directing group
and the formation of this metallacyclic intermediate.
Also the minimization of by-products.

However, one of the still current challenges
is the scarce number of methodologies developed

using earth-abundant first-row metals, and
we turn our attention toward cobalt.

Over the past five years, as you can see in
the graph, cobalt complexes have demonstrated
their capability to perform this type of functionalizations.

The flourishing of this field is not only
that cobalt is a cost-effective alternative

to analogous rhodium-based ones, but also
because these type of complexes exhibit unique
reactivity.

However, from our point of view, at the time
when we're starting this project back in 2016,

there was a major limitation that was preventing us
to bring cobalt to its ultimate capability.

And it was the limited understanding of the nature
of the reactive species or the mechanism involved
in this transformation.

Probably due to the proposed reversible nature
of this C-H activation step that happened
at that time to detect these A type of intermediates.

As we used to say in the lab, we started this
project chasing unicorns, because everyone

proposed these complexes, but no one saw them
until we started this research line.

So, I'm going to give you a brief overview
of our initial contribution in the field in
the context of oxidative alkyne annulation.

We were able to access this A type of intermediates
through an alternative route using a really

important reaction in organometallic chemistry
and oxidative addition.

Using this acetonitrile as a stabilizing ligand
that is crucial for accessing otherwise highly
reactive intermediate.

Next we tested the catalytic efficiency of
our cobalt cycle versus the most widely used

Cp*Co(III) catalysts, because normally it's
envisioned that if you can isolate a compound,
that means that it's not going to be reactive.
But in our case it was completely the opposite.
Our pre-catalyst is more active.

Indeed, we can lower the catalyst loading to
just one more percent. This is one of

the lowest in this type of cobalt-catalyzed
transformation.

We were even able to observe a resting state,
other reactive intermediate, under catalytic
conditions. That turned out to be this 7-member-ring cobaltacycle due to the reactivity of

this alkyne, that inserts in this carbon-cobalt
bond.

We were able to catch this intermediate and
characterize it with different analytic techniques.

When we published this work last year in Angewandte
Chemie, they offered us to design a cover.

The analogy of a camera taking picture, we
thought that it was a really visual one.

Before finishing, if you want to know more
about our recent advances, please check our
last paper.

We are really excited because we were able
to overcome the reversible nature of the C-H

metalation step and isolate a more-reactive
cobalt intermediate.
But not only that, we were able to design a more-efficient transformation using this captured

intermediate by unraveling the boosting effect
of this perfluorinated alcohol, HFIP, not

only in the C-H activation state, but also
under catalytic conditions.

Before finishing, I hope I was able to transmit to
you my passion for mechanistic studies.

My home-take message is that the capture of
reaction intermediates can be extremely a powerful

tool for boosting the synergy between mechanistic
studies and catalysis in order to promote
the rational design of more-efficient transformations.

And this is the most important slide of my
talk.

I want to thank the former and current members
of my group.
They are awesome.

Sometimes it's really challenging to go to
a new lab, and they took the risk.
I'm really grateful for that.

I also want to thank the funding, especially
ICIQ, for giving me the opportunity to start
my own independent group back in Spain.
This empty space is really important for me.
I want to thanks my former advisors.
They are awesome.

They still help me a lot to navigate in this
new independent career.

And of course, my family and friends because they
support me in this sometimes rocky road.

Again, thanks Chemical & Engineering News
for this opportunity.
Enjoy the coffee break.
